channel.title: Posts on sailing on lambdas ⛵️
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on sailing on lambdas ⛵️

item.title: Lisp: cons, car and cdr
item.description: There is a footnote in chapter 2 of SICP that explains what the names of these popular Lisp primitives stand for - The name cons stands for “construct.” The names car and cdr derive from the original implementation of Lisp on the IBM 704. That machine had an addressing scheme that allowed one to reference the “address” and “decrement” parts of a memory location. car stands for “Contents of Address part of Register” and cdr (pronounced “could-er”) stands for “Contents of Decrement part of Register.
item.content:
There is a footnote in chapter 2 of SICP that explains what the names of these popular Lisp primitives stand for -

The name cons stands for “construct.” The names car and cdr derive from the original implementation of Lisp on the IBM 704. That machine had an addressing scheme that allowed one to reference the “address” and “decrement” parts of a memory location. car stands for “Contents of Address part of Register” and cdr (pronounced “could-er”) stands for “Contents of Decrement part of Register.”

item.title: Siri Touch Typing Easter Egg in macOS
item.description: If you type the home row keys of the QWERTY layout into macOS’ Spotlight Search twice, Siri understands that you are touch typing. Steps to reproduce Make sure you’re connected to the Internet. Type asdfjkl;asdfjkl; into Spotlight Search.
item.content:
If you type the home row keys of the QWERTY layout into macOS’ Spotlight Search twice, Siri understands that you are touch typing.

Steps to reproduce

  1. Make sure you’re connected to the Internet.
  2. Type asdfjkl;asdfjkl; into Spotlight Search.

item.title: ArgumentNullException / Don't forget the precedent!
item.description: At work this week, I discovered a quirk in the .NET API. An ArgumentException is thrown when one of the arguments to a method is invalid. A more specific ArgumentException is an ArgumentNullException which (as you may have guessed) is thrown when an argument is invalid because it is null. The funny thing is that while the base class provides this constructor - public ArgumentException (string message, string paramName); the one provided by the derived class is -
item.content:
At work this week, I discovered a quirk in the .NET API.

An ArgumentException is thrown when one of the arguments to a method is invalid. A more specific ArgumentException is an ArgumentNullException which (as you may have guessed) is thrown when an argument is invalid because it is null.

The funny thing is that while the base class provides this constructor -

public ArgumentException (string message, string paramName);

the one provided by the derived class is -

public ArgumentNullException (string paramName, string message);

The order of the parameters is swapped!

Inconsistencies like these can lead to confusion. In our case, we ended up with code that was passing arguments to the constructor in the wrong order -

throw new ArgumentNullException(messageArg, paramNameArg);

The moral

Always strive for consistent interfaces.

Breaking reasonable expectations by creating inconsistencies introduces accidental complexity. And for us mere mortals, accidental complexity is the enemy!

item.title: Setting Up This Site
item.description: A quick update about this site - I’m in the middle of setting it up so that it’s just as I’d want (or failing that, till all the essentials are met). Here’s what I’m working on - On the technical side, I need to get this site deployed. (It wasn’t when I wrote this!). I’m using Hugo - the static site generator. Also, need to enable comments so that we can talk to each other :P Importantly, I want this site to be organized so that it’s easy to navigate and view related content.
item.content:
A quick update about this site - I’m in the middle of setting it up so that it’s just as I’d want (or failing that, till all the essentials are met).

Here’s what I’m working on -

  1. On the technical side, I need to get this site deployed. (It wasn’t when I wrote this!). I’m using Hugo - the static site generator.
  2. Also, need to enable comments so that we can talk to each other :P
  3. Importantly, I want this site to be organized so that it’s easy to navigate and view related content. Maybe simple classfication features like Tags and Categories will do it. But I’ll think some more and experiment a bit.

P.S. Since I’m learning Hugo and Markdown, you might see posts about these under a Learning category.

item.title: First Blog Post
item.description: A new blog is born. Readers, you are welcome!
item.content: A new blog is born. Readers, you are welcome!
